Studies have shown that prone positioning was associated with improved oxygenation and a decrease in CO 2 retention, leading to reduced mortality, in patients with influenza, MERS, or ARDS.
72
,
73 As a result, a Chinese expert consensus recommends that patients be prone for ≥ 12 hours a day when PaO 2/FiO 2 < 150 mm Hg.
74 Before placing the patient in prone position, oral secretions should be suctioned regularly to help keep the artificial airway open. In addition, COVID-19 patients suffer from copious proteinaceous exudates in their lungs and airways.
75
,
76 Aspiration of sputum can help to keep the airway intact and potentially improve sample collection and the accuracy of SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid detection.
77 The patient’s position should be assessed and changed regularly to avoid decubitus skin injury. Elevating the head of the bed 30-45 degrees,
78 suctioning out oropharyngeal secretions, and monitoring the pressure of a rebreathing bag can help to prevent ventilator-associated pneumonia.
